articles.headline: U.S. Plans Stiffer Rules Protecting Retiree Cash
articles.snippet: The rules would eliminate some loopholes that allow brokers to avoid acting as fiduciaries when providing advice on retirement accounts like 401(k)’s.
articles.abstract: The rules would eliminate some loopholes that allow brokers to avoid acting as fiduciaries when providing advice on retirement accounts like 401(k)’s.
articles.lead_paragraph: Federal regulators on Tuesday proposed rules, more than four years in the making, to provide greater consumer protection for retirement savings, requiring a broader group of investment professionals to act in their customers’ best interests when handling their retirement money.

articles.headline: Atlanta School Workers Sentenced in Test Score Cheating Case
articles.snippet: The sentences imposed ranged from six months in jail to seven years in prison. The educators were convicted of falsifying test scores.
articles.abstract: The sentences imposed ranged from six months in jail to seven years in prison. The educators were convicted of falsifying test scores.
articles.lead_paragraph: ATLANTA — In an unexpectedly harsh sentence after a polarizing six-year ordeal, eight of the 10 educators convicted of racketeering in one of the nation’s largest public school cheating scandals were sentenced to prison terms of up to seven years Tuesday after they refused to take sentencing deals that were predicated on their acceptance of responsibility and a waiver of their right to appeal.
articles.byline: By Richard Fausset and Alan Blinder

articles.headline: In Race for Medicare Dollars, Nursing Home Care May Lag
articles.snippet: Some facilities trying to attract higher-paying Medicare patients are not up to the challenge of providing the needed care; others are shunning Medicaid patients.
articles.abstract: Some facilities trying to attract higher-paying Medicare patients are not up to the challenge of providing the needed care; others are shunning Medicaid patients.
articles.lead_paragraph: Promises of “decadent” hot baths on demand, putting greens and gurgling waterfalls to calm the mind: These luxurious touches rarely conjure images of a stay in a nursing home.

articles.headline: A Call to Look Past Sustainable Development
articles.snippet: An “eco-modernist” strategy that argues against “sustainable development” will require more intensive use of land, and more energy.
articles.abstract: An “eco-modernist” strategy that argues against “sustainable development” will require more intensive use of land, and more energy.
articles.lead_paragraph: The average citizen of Nepal consumes about 100 kilowatt-hours of electricity in a year. Cambodians make do with 160. Bangladeshis are better off, consuming, on average, 260.

articles.headline: Google Expected to Face Antitrust Charges in Europe
articles.snippet: Europe’s antitrust chief is expected to accuse the search giant of using its dominant position to favor its own services, a case that could force a change in its practices.
articles.abstract: Europe’s antitrust chief is expected to accuse the search giant of using its dominant position to favor its own services, a case that could force a change in its practices.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON — The European Commission is said to be planning to charge Google with using its dominant position in online search to favor the company’s own services over others, in what would be one of the biggest antitrust cases here since regulators went after Microsoft.
articles.byline: By Mark Scott and James Kanter

articles.headline: The Robotics Inventors Who Are Trying to Take the ‘Hard’ Out of Hardware
articles.snippet: A handful of low-budget innovators are working to reinvent rigid, heavy machines and robots with materials that are soft, light, cheap and squeezable.
articles.abstract: A handful of low-budget innovators are working to reinvent rigid, heavy machines and robots with materials that are soft, light, cheap and squeezable.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — In a converted pipe organ factory in the city’s Mission District, Saul Griffith works on products that are smarter, cheaper and, above all, squiggly.

articles.headline: Centuries of Italian History Are Unearthed in Quest to Fix Toilet
articles.snippet: As he tried to find a sewage pipe, Luciano Faggiano dug his way past a Messapian tomb, a Roman granary, a Franciscan chapel and even etchings from the Knights Templar.
articles.abstract: As he tried to find a sewage pipe, Luciano Faggiano dug his way past a Messapian tomb, a Roman granary, a Franciscan chapel and even etchings from the Knights Templar.
articles.lead_paragraph: LECCE, Italy — All Luciano Faggiano wanted when he purchased the seemingly unremarkable building at 56 Via Ascanio Grandi was to open a trattoria. The only problem was the toilet.

articles.headline: Blackwater’s Legacy Goes Beyond Public View
articles.snippet: Private security firms have matured from bit players on the edge of global conflicts to multinational companies that guard oil fields, analyze intelligence and fight insurgents.
articles.abstract: Private security firms have matured from bit players on the edge of global conflicts to multinational companies that guard oil fields, analyze intelligence and fight insurgents.
articles.lead_paragraph: By the time four former Blackwater security guards were sentenced this week to long prison terms for the 2007 fatal shooting of 14 civilians in Iraq, the man who sent the contractors there had long since moved on from the country and the company he made notorious.
articles.byline: By James Risen and Matthew Rosenberg

articles.headline: Europe Challenges Google, Seeing Violations of Its Antitrust Law
articles.snippet: The charge focuses on accusations that the company diverts traffic from its rivals to favor its own products and services, particularly websites for shopping.
articles.abstract: The charge focuses on accusations that the company diverts traffic from its rivals to favor its own products and services, particularly websites for shopping.
articles.lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — The European Union’s antitrust chief on Wednesday formally accused Google of abusing its dominance in web searches, bringing charges that could limit the giant American tech company’s moneymaking prowess.
articles.byline: By James Kanter and Mark Scott
